title: I Like That! How our eyes and brains interact to determine what we like and dislike
description: This video explores how things we see (visual stimuli) affect emotional states and interact with our memories and higher order thinking (cognition) to produce preferences and behavior. This basic framework is adapted from human and animal behavior research. We use this framework throughout the middle school-targeted lesson below. In the lesson, students perform an experiment to understand their own preferences and dive into research on fish, exploring how sensitivity to different frequencies of light affects mate preferences. We dive into this topic in detail in our second video supporting this lesson.
lessonRelevance: Sets up an experiment students will run on themselves to understand how emotion, memory, and higher-order connections explain their own preferences.

title: Images for Part 1 Experiment
lessonRelevance: Visual stimuli for the experiment students will run.

title: How we see color - Colm Kelleher
lessonRelevance: Nice explainer of what color is: different wavelengths of light reflected from objects and detected by our eyes and brain.

title: The Science of Color Perception
lessonRelevance: This neat video adds a bit more detail about color perception. We carried the "cones" characters into our original video (next in the playlist).

title: How do we know what a fish likes? (And can we predict it?)
lessonRelevance: Follow in the footsteps of Drs. Tamra Mendelson and Tory Williams! Explains basics of how color vision works in humans and fish.

title: Creature Stats Character Sheets
